description: To the Editor:

title: Mission Accomplished For Devils at Garden
description: Unlike Game 1, in which they earned a solid 4-3 victory in double overtime, the Devils experienced a letdown last night and suffered the consequences.

title: HOME DEPOT INC. (HD,N)
description: Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter net income surged nearly 31 percent, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, as expansion into the Midwest and Canada fueled a strong sales increase.

title: Killed by Her Friends, Sons of the Heartland
description: In the middle of a silent country night last August, 17-year-old Michelle Jensen was shot to death. Her body was left along a dusty rural road, near a cornfield not far from the center of the city.

title: The Eclipse Made a Theater of Shadows
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight New Segregationism, President Urges Students
description: President Clinton, who attended segregated public schools until he went to college, said today that young people should not squander the gains of desegregation and should work to curtail violence and rebuild families.

title: J. C. Penney and Dayton Post Gains in Earnings
description: J. C. Penney Company and the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fourth- and fifth-largest retailers, each reported yesterday that their first-quarter earnings rose 30 percent, exceeding Wall Street's expectations.

title: Theater in Review
description: Loved Less (The History of Hell) Via Theater Downtown Art Company 64 East Fourth Street East Village Through May 28 Conceived, written and directed by Brian Jucha; assistant director and stage manager, Robin Riddell; created in collaboration with the Company. Set by Sarah Edkins; lighting by Roma Flowers; costumes by Kasia Walicka-Maimone; sound by Mr. Jucha; additional music by Rod Hohl; puppets by Ms. Edkins. Presented by Downtown Art Company, Ryan Gilliam, artistic director; Cliff Scott, producing director.

title: Boys Are More Comfortable With Sex Than Girls Are, Survey Finds
description: High school girls are less comfortable with their sexual experiences than are their male counterparts, according to a new nationwide survey of high school students.

title: Niagara Mohawk Sale
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said today that it had hired the investment banking firm Goldman, Sachs & Company to help sell its Hydra-Co Enterprises unit. Niagara Mohawk, based here, said it had decided to sell the unit after evaluating recent changes in the unregulated power business in New York and elsewhere. Hydra-Co develops and operates electric generating power plants.

title: Critic's Notebook; Even Cannes's Fray Can't Chase Away Hugh Grant's Smile
description: Hugh Grant came here and stayed in a youth hostel when he was 19 ("which was charming as well"), but things are a trifle different this year. Now he is installed at the Hotel du Cap d'Antibes, the peaceful, costly, out-of-town oasis traditionally used by emissaries from le tout Hollywood who choose to avoid crowds. "Ah, the sun's up," joked the director Mike Newell, sitting on a terrace overlooking the hotel's formal gardens and watching Mr. Grant lope into view. "Here comes the sun."

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal to extend the overrun area for the main runway at La Guardia Airport included erroneous figures from the Port Authority on the length of the existing overrun area and of the proposed extension. The current area is 60 feet long, not 100 feet; the extension would be 400 feet, not 460 feet.

title: In Clinton Harassment Suit, the Stories Conflict; Statute of Limitations
description: To the Editor:

title: Julia A. Bissell, 87, a Patron Of the Arts and Restorations
description: Julia Andrews Bissell, a patron of the arts and moving force in the restoration of the historic Kenmore mansion and museum in Fredericksburg, Va., died on Sunday at the Medical College of Georgia Hospital in Augusta. She was 87 and had homes in Chadds Ford, Pa., and Aiken, S.C.

title: Review/Ballet Theater; Bocca and Ferri in 'Manon'
description: Kenneth MacMillan's "Manon" has its choreographic high points. But it is so padded that it requires strong dancers as Manon and Des Grieux to prevent it from becoming lugubrious.

title: Stress in Teens Can Increase Risk Of Early High Blood Pressure
description: THE angst of adolescence can stir enough physical distress to more than double the risk of early onset of hypertension in some boys and girls, a new study has found.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY TEACHERS UNION SUPPORTS OVERHAUL

title: State Warns Of Mercury In Its Lakes
description: Deep in the heart of the Pine Barrens, surrounded by the protected forests of Wharton State Park, Batsto Lake presents a picture of New Jersey that never emerges when late-night talk show hosts make jokes about the state.

title: Steven Keats, 48, Film and TV Actor
description: Steven Keats, a screen, television and stage actor, who played Carol Kane's husband in the film "Hester Street," was found dead on May 8 in his Manhattan apartment. He was 48.

title: ATCO Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago revenue is restated to reflect an accounting change.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said higher earnings resulted from strong performances by its utilities subsidiaries. Because of seasonal factors and the timing of rate applications, it said the subsidiaries' results are not necessarily indicative of full-year results.

title: De La Hoya Has Advice for Chavez
description: OSCAR DE LA HOYA, America's only boxing gold medalist of the 1992 Olympic Games, once idolized JULIO CESAR CHAVEZ, Mexico's ranking hero. But De La Hoya had nothing but contempt yesterday for his former hero. "I believe he should quit now, now that he's ahead," said De La Hoya.

title: Voices Rise For Sake Of Youths
description: THE point, Webnesh Hylton made emphatically clear, is that the City Hall grown-ups looking to trim the budget by cutting back on Youth Services have their priorities wrong.

title: Working Double Time, The Nuggets Stay Alive
description: Nuggets 109, Jazz 101

title: Patriots Sign McGinest, First-Round Pick
description: WILLIE McGINEST, who the Patriots hope will succeed the retired ANDRE TIPPETT as a premier pass rusher, signed yesterday with New England 23 days after being taken with the fourth pick of the National Football League.

title: Islamic Militants Slay 2 Settlers in Hebron
description: Two Israeli settlers were shot to death today by Islamic militants just south of this West Bank town, and Israel's army commander warned that the violence might be a foretaste of what settlements would face under Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip.

title: Bonn Journal; His Gift: To Look Germany Straight in the Eye
description: For 10 years, President Richard von Weizsacker has been the conscience of his country, insisting again and again to his fellow Germans that the only solid foundation for their future is acknowledgment of the past.

title: Suns' Ainge Is Fined $5,000 by N.B.A.
description: DANNY AINGE of the Phoenix Suns was fined $5,000 yesterday for throwing a ball into the face of Houston's MARIO ELIE during Game 3 of the Western Conference semifinals. The incident occurred in the closing seconds of Houston's 118-102 victory last Friday. Following a Houston basket, Ainge took the ball out of bounds and threw it baseball-style into Elie's face. Ainge said it was an accident. (AP)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Debate Over Milk and an Artificial Hormone; Move Over, Elsie: Recasting the Cow As a Political Animal
description: KID RED PAULINE and Lisa's Pride of Ronnybrook Farm Dairy didn't expect to become political animals. Like most 2,000-pound Holsteins, they'd never imagined anything other than a reasonably long life of a familiar green pasture, a predictable milking schedule and the steady twang of the country-and-western music that is played in their barn.

title: Sports of The Times; Whose Fault Is Capriati's Runaway?
description: "WEDNESDAY morning at five o'clock as the day begins," a young woman in Britain in the early months of 1967 left a cryptic note to her parents and turned the backdoor key. "Stepping outside she is free."

title: Books of The Times; Past and Present Mingling in a State of Mind
description: Big Dreams Into the Heart of California By Bill Barich Illustrated. 546 pages. Pantheon. $24.

title: Cigarette Maker Takes the Offensive on Capitol Hill
description: The political skirmish between tobacco companies and their Capitol Hill critics escalated today as a witness at a House hearing accused a cigarette maker of trying to stifle his testimony, and the same company subpoenaed six news reporters and two members of the House.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAYER GROUP A.G., Leverkusen, Germany, the chemicals company, will buy two rubber divisions from Huls A.G., a chemicals subsidary of Veba A.G., Dusseldorf, Germany. The operations have combined annual sales of $89.3 million. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. HUGHES SPACE AND COMMUNICATIONS CO., El Segundo, Calif., a maker of communications satellites and a unit of the General Motors Corp., won a $61.5 million contract to build a telecommunications satellite for Malaysia.

title: Court Backs Arbitration For Police and Firefighters
description: The State Supreme Court today reaffirmed a 17-year-old law that requires binding arbitration to settle contract impasses between local governments and their police and firefighter unions.

title: Rangers Surmount a Pair of Penalty Whistles
description: Two whistles, and the Rangers were facing a crisis. Their happy cruise through the Stanley Cup playoffs already having reached an abrupt halt, the Rangers had been displaying the assertiveness and attentiveness they need to cope with the Devils. They had established a forceful early edge in a game they needed to tie the Eastern Conference final series. They were winning more face-offs. They were creating more opportunities and taking more shots.

title: U.S. Says Man Bilked Investors of $130 Million
description: A California man has bilked thousands of investors across the country out of as much as $130 million, money they thought was being invested in low-income housing projects, Federal prosecutors in Minnesota charged yesterday.

title: Suffolk Man Killed By Officer in Chase
description: A 38-year-old Melville, L.I., man was fatally shot in the head by a Suffolk County police officer late Monday night after a three-mile chase, the authorities said today.

title: Earlier Mishap Reported at Site Of Derailment
description: The investigation into the derailment of an Amtrak passenger train that apparently struck a dislodged trailer jutting from a passing freight train turned today to reports that the same freight line had recently had a similar but less serious accident.

title: Executive Changes
description: COLOROCS CORP., Atlanta, a distributor of color printed paper production equipment, named Albert R. Tetrault president and chief executive. FRITO-LAY INC., Plano, Tex., named Sean F. Orr senior vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: Most of Clintons' Wealth Held by Mrs. Clinton, Disclosure Form Shows
description: The White House made public financial disclosure forms today that showed that most of the wealth of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, is in the name of Mrs. Clinton.

title: Two Players Are Suspended
description: Sergei Fedorov, a finalist in the balloting for the Hart Trophy as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League, will be under suspension when next season opens.

title: Gilbert Roland Is Dead at 88; Actor From Silent Films to TV
description: Gilbert Roland, a lean, dynamic and virile performer who began his career as a Latin lover in silent films and over four decades became one of Hollywood's ablest and most popular character actors, died on Sunday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88.

title: Barbecue: The (Unwritten) Lore of the Land
description: SPRING is cherished by many food lovers for the first tiny asparagus, tender greens or delicate fiddlehead ferns. To some, however, the arrival of the season means just one thing: it's finally warm enough to stay up all night cooking pork over smoldering logs in a dirt pit.

title: Police Need More Rotation Among Precincts
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA MAY ALLOW U.S. BROADCASTS
description: China took another step today toward meeting President Clinton's human rights conditions, a sign of progress that the Administration quickly highlighted, apparently in an effort to prepare the public for a decision to renew Beijing's trade benefits with only a few symbolic conditions attached.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1991, former President GERALD R. FORD presented the Nelson A. Rockefeller Public Service Award to former Secretary of State HENRY A. KISSINGER. When Mr. Ford receives the same award next Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria, the individual doing the honors will be Mr. Kissinger.

title: Food Notes
description: Tops for Wedding Cakes

title: Guilty Plea In Fraud Case
description: A former commodities broker at Prudential Securities Inc. pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the brokerage firm's health insurer of about $40,000.

title: Till Death Do This Doubles Team Part
description: They are the French Open's reigning doubles champions, but there is nothing Gallic about the brash brothers Jensen. The ambidextrous Luke and his sidekick sibling, Murphy, are determined to save doubles from the nefarious clutches of industry insiders who want it phased out for lack of income and interest.

title: Fed's Move Heartens Markets
description: Financial markets surged in reaction to the Federal Reserve Board's decision to raise two key short-term interest rates yesterday.

title: Stocks Rise in Support Of Fed's Move on Rates
description: In a paradoxical show of exuberance, stock traders bid up share prices on the leading indexes yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates, a move that would seemingly hurt stocks by making borrowing more expensive.

title: Crucial Freeway Link, Damaged in Quake, Reopens Early
description: A section of Interstate 5 in far-north Los Angeles reopened today, four months after the Jan. 17 Northridge earthquake and not a moment too soon for tens of thousands of commuters and truck drivers who have suffered through lengthy delays and detours.

title: Egypt Should Investigate Lawyer's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: German State Eases Its Policy on Drug Arrests
description: After a recent court decision that removed criminal penalties for the possession of small amounts of marijuana and hashish in Germany, officials in the country's most populous state say the police there will no longer arrest people for possessing small amounts of any drug, including cocaine, heroin, morphine, amphetamine pills or LSD.

title: Compuware Corp.(CWPR,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Maxxam Reaches Pact In Shareholders' Suits
description: A tentative $52 million settlement was reached yesterday between Maxxam Inc. and former shareholders of the Pacific Lumber Company, ending a bitter, nine-year legal battle that began when Maxxam acquired Pacific Lumber in 1985.

title: Wife of Missing Libyan Says Qaddafi Aide Sought to Muffle Her
description: The wife of a prominent Libyan dissident who disappeared in Egypt five months ago says a senior Libyan official offered her money to tone down her campaign against the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, widely viewed as having ordered the dissident's abduction in Cairo on Dec. 10.

title: Housing Shows Vigor Even as Starts Slip 2.5%
description: Housing starts dropped 2.5 percent in April, led by declines in the South and West, the Commerce Department said today.

title: International Recovery Corp.(INT,N) reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: b-After a net loss of $ 3,717,000, which included a loss from operations of discontinued Environmental Services segment (net of applicable income taxes) of $ 1,793,000 and a loss on disposal of Environmental Services segment including provision of $ 1,350,000 for operating losses during phase-out period (net of applicable income taxes) of $ 1,922,000.The company said the fiscal 1994 included a loss on the settlement of shareholder litigation which consituted 16 cents a share.

title: Market Place; The Latest Sales Pitch From T. Boone Pickens
description: Remember T. Boone Pickens? He is the corporate raider who said during the 1980's that the best place to prospect for cheap, though mismanaged, oil and natural gas reserves was on Wall Street.

title: In America; After Brown, What?
description: One of the many witnesses who testified in the Brown v. Board of Education case as it made its way toward the Supreme Court and history was a sociologist named Louisa Pinkham Holt. She was among the experts chosen by the plaintiffs to support their contention that enforced school segregation damaged black children.

title: House Kills a Bill to Require Registration of Private Sales of Handguns
description: The State House of Representatives today killed a gun-control measure intended to restrict the secondary market in handguns by making all sales of pistols, even between private individuals, subject to registration and waiting periods.

title: Despite a Loss, Lloyd's Sees Path to Recovery
description: Lloyd's of London said today that its losses had narrowed in its most recently completed accounting year, and that all signs pointed to an eventual recovery from the deep financial problems that had pushed it near the brink of collapse.

title: Prudential May Cut Unit
description: Prudential Securities Inc. said yesterday that it might consider reducing its junk bond trading after the resignations of the co-heads of its high-yield trading group.

title: Eating Well: The Debate Over Milk and an Artificial Hormone; More Milk, More Confusion: What Should the Label Say?
description: PUBLIC apprehension about milk from cows treated with the artificial bovine growth hormone is not going away, despite the efforts of the hormone's manufacturer to allay the fear.

title: House Backs Independence For Social Security Agency
description: The House voted today to detach the Social Security Administration from the Department of Health and Human Services and make it an independent agency, ostensibly to protect its trove of money from the "political mischief" of free-spending bureaucrats.

title: U.N. Council, Split on Iraq, Keeps Its Ban
description: The United Nations Security Council was divided today over the future of economic sanctions against Iraq, with more than half the 15 members ready to say the Administration of Presdient Saddam Hussein is making progress toward meeting conditions for lifting the ban on its sale of oil. But the United States and some other members remain skeptical.

title: Global Village? Just Check The Menu
description: Where are we eating tonight? A French bistro? That little Thai place? A trattoria? A sushi bar? The larger the group, the longer the debate.

title: CBS's Fall Lineup: Comedies, Drama and a Nod to the Young
description: CBS announced a fall lineup of programs yesterday that included three new comedies, four new dramas and a modest effort to pull in some younger, urban viewers.

title: Officials Apparently Lagged in Tracking Slain Truant Girl
description: Connecticut officials apparently squandered several opportunities to track down a 10-year-old Bridgeport, Conn., girl who had not attended school since last September and whose slashed body was found Saturday night, discarded near the squalid house she shared with her mother, three younger siblings and her mother's boyfriend.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Republicans have no monopoly on tributes: R. SARGENT SHRIVER is among the Democrats reaping rewards this year.

title: The Other John Malkovich: Director
description: As an actor, John Malkovich repeatedly transforms himself. In his words, he can "go into other people's skins." These people happen to include some of the strangest, most obsessive characters in movies and theater: the volcanic Pale in Lanford Wilson's play "Burn This" and, last summer, the killer in Clint Eastwood's film "In the Line of Fire." In his next movie, Stephen Frears's "Mary Reilly," to be filmed this summer in England, he will face the doubly daunting task of playing Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (opposite Julia Roberts in the title role as the housemaid).

title: Review/Recital; Mussorgsky's 'Pictures' With Pogorelich's Tints
description: Ivo Pogorelich, once a punkish and raffish stage presence whose pianism seemed partly intended to shock, has now settled into his maturity. There is a piano competition bearing his name, he is described in program notes as an advocate of music education for young people, and in Carnegie Hall on Monday night he gave a performance of Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition" that was a pianistic tour de force.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Alan Alda; Hawkeye Turns Mean, Sensitively
description: THE first thing Alan Alda wants to know when he arrives is whether everything is O.K. He has chosen the restaurant, Orso; he hopes that's O.K. He has asked for a table outside, on the patio. Is that O.K.?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Burlington Northern Inc., Fort Worth, is selling $150 million of notes due in 1999 at 100 to yield 7.4 percent through Morgan Stanley. The noncallable issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Bringing the World Into Your Kitchen
description: NEVER one to be caught napping when a trend starts rattling the pantry, Sheila Lukins has tapped into the new global smorgasbord with her latest book, a 591-page tome, "All Around the World Cookbook" (Workman; $27.95 cloth, $18.95 paper). A result of two years worth of visits to 33 countries, it is a whirlwind tour on the order of "If It's Tuesday This Must Be Belgium." Or Tunisia. Or Jamaica. Or Thailand.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about murder cases against teen-agers in New York City last year misstated the sentence received by one defendant, Jeffrey Washington. It was 5 years to life in prison, not 5 to 15 years.

title: Off the Menu
description: Waiting for Troisgros

title: Medicare's Big Cigarette Burn
description: Smoking, as its adherents like to point out, is a private choice. But it is also a choice with public consequences. Just how extraordinary those consequences are is evident in a report issued this week by Joseph A. Califano Jr., head of Columbia University's Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse.

title: INSIDE
description: Prom Rekindles Bias Case

title: Aftermath of '54 Ruling Disheartens the Browns
description: Linda Brown Thompson's voice betrays weariness when she talks about school desegregation.

title: Review/Theater: Kindertransport; Another Perspective On the Holocaust
description: Just as there are earnest, hard-working people who make their contributions to society without flash or fanfare, there are earnest, hard-working plays.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO. (HWP,N)
description: Buoyed by strong demand for personal computers and growth in ink-jet printers, the Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 18 percent in its fiscal second quarter, to $408 million, or $1.56 a share. The gains came on a 23 percent increase in revenue, to $6.25 billion.

title: Investor's Fund Makes Move On Olympia & York in U.S.
description: The investment fund run by Leon Black, one of America's most aggressive deal makers and richest men, moved a step closer this week to taking control of Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), the largest holder of commercial real estate in New York City, executives of Olympia & York said yesterday.

title: Clinton's New Policy on Haiti Yields Little Progress So Far
description: President Clinton's new strategy to restore democracy to Haiti has thus far failed to weaken the ruling military junta, elicit help from other countries in resettling refugees or stem criticism by lawmakers, refugee groups and human rights leaders.

title: Theater in Review
description: Sancho and Don Intar Hispanic American Arts Center 420 West 42d Street Clinton Through June 5 Conceived by Sigfrido Aguilar and Jim Calder; music by Andy Teirstein; lighting by Paul Clay; literary advisior, Janet M. Izzo. Presented by Intar Hispanic American Arts Center, Max Ferra, artistic director.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CYNTHIA HARVEY, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, had a double-barreled reason to celebrate yesterday: she marked her 20th anniversary with the company and her 37th birthday.

title: DeAnza Property Sale
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc. has agreed to acquire 11 manufactured housing communities and the property management business of DeAnza Group Inc. for $189 million. Manufactured Home, of Chicago, said the transaction was expected to be completed in the third quarter. The sale is subject to the approval of DeAnza Group's limited partners.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: Motta Returns as Mavericks' Coach
description: DICK MOTTA, the original coach of the Dallas Mavericks, returned to the job yesterday, hoping to restore respectability to the National Basketball Association's worst team. The Mavericks chose Motta, 62, as the successor to QUINN BUCKNER, who was dismissed two weeks ago after a 13-69 record in his only season.

title: With Surgery Behind Him, Simms Starts on Road Back
description: Phil Simms participated in the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic at the Upper Montclair Country Club today. But not the way he wanted. He didn't have to worry about his distance off the tee. His concern was how far his voice would carry.

title: Rangers Bounce Back as the Devils Draw a Blank
description: When the history of this gripping Rangers-Devils series is written, the Game 2 chapter will have several subtitles. One could be "Richter Ties the Shutout Record." Another might say "Anderson Finally Scores." A third might read "The Thrill of Penalty-Killing."

title: Al Unser Sr., Near 55, Retires From Racing
description: Al Unser Sr., who could easily claim to be the most competitive driver in the history of the Indianapolis 500, announced his retirement from racing at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway yesterday after struggling to qualify for his 28th Indy 500.

title: Israelis and P.L.O. Go on Patrol Together
description: One sweltering afternoon in Jericho this week, Israeli border police officers and a fighter from the Palestine Liberation Organization leaned over the engine of a stalled Israeli jeep, trying to coax it back to life so they could start their patrol together.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE
description: Princeton

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Orsulak Performs A Salvage Operation
description: Joe Orsulak does not fancy himself to be anything more than a workaday ballplayer. He plays good defense. He has a good arm. He's good at moving runners over and executing the hit-and-run.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: In Clinton Harassment Suit, the Stories Conflict; Later Will Also Do
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Moves to Oust Principal In Furor on Interracial Dating
description: After a principal's attempts to discourage interracial couples from attending the high school prom in Weedowee, Ala., the Justice Department today reopened a 24-year-old desegregation case and asked a Federal court to remove the principal.

title: Teachers Back Changes in School Boards
description: For the first time, the powerful New York City teachers' union has thrown its support behind a plan to overhaul the community school boards, some of which have been plagued for years by corruption and patronage. The proposal would change the way the boards are elected and strip them of the authority to hire principals and other school administrators.

title: Bulls Say United They Stand
description: The three-time defending champion Chicago Bulls would like the world to think that they carry a steady confidence into the resumption of their deadlocked playoff series with the Knicks.

title: Real Estate
description: IN one of the largest leasing transactions in New Jersey this year, the Margaretten Financial Corporation, a mortgage banking company based in Perth Amboy, is taking 97,500 square feet in an office park in nearby Edison.

title: Alfred Nier, 82; Physicist Helped Foster A-Bomb
description: Alfred O. C. Nier, a physicist at the University of Minnesota whose early work on lead and uranium isotopes helped determine the age of the earth and usher in the atomic age, died on Monday in Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis. He was 82.

title: Applied Materials (AMAT,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 7,000,000, or 8 cents a share.Share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Oct. 5, 1993.Applied Materials said that its sales in the latest second quarter reflect accelerating shipments of its equipment as semiconductor manufacturers increase their manufacturing capacity to address strong current orders for microprocessors, logic and memory devices.

title: In a Bleak Camp, Rwanda Refugees Say Each Tribe Is Joining in the Killing
description: For the first time since Rwandans by the tens of thousands began fleeing to Tanzania two weeks ago from army-led massacres in their homeland, refugees are bringing eyewitness accounts of killings by rebel soldiers, too, United Nations officials here say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 ISRAEL OFFERS DEAL ON GOLAN Israel has offered to withdraw from the Golan Heights in three phases in return for peace and normal relations with Syria, officials close to the indirect peace talks said. A1 Two Israeli settlers were shot by militants south of Hebron. A14

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day yesterday about the Foster Wheeler Energy Corporation misstated the number of contracts that the company received to build two coal-fired steam generators in the Hubei province of China. It was one contract, not two.

title: Corrections
description: A review of new fur styles yesterday on the Fashion page misspelled the name of a furrier. He is Jerry Sorbara, not Sorbaya.

title: A TELEPHONE ROLE BY TIME WARNER
description: In the first plan of its type in the nation, Time Warner Inc. intends to use its cable-television system in Rochester next year to provide telephone service to residential and business customers in competition with the local phone company.

title: 40 Years After Brown, Segregation Persists
description: Topeka Boulevard, a nine-mile-long stretch of commerce, fulfills most needs of the 120,000 people in this city on the plains. But the four-lane thoroughfare also serves an unintended purpose: dividing the races. Whites live to the west, blacks to the east.

title: Easing of Capacity Limit Cited in Tanker Explosion
description: The explosion of a gasoline tanker truck on a Long Island Expressway ramp in Queens on Sunday probably would not have happened had a ban on bigger trucks in the city still been in force, some truck safety experts said yesterday.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: U.S. Clashes With Russia Over Bosnia
description: Beneath the show of unity on Bosnia and Herzegovina finally contrived last week by the United States, Russia and the European Union, a sharp diplomatic dispute flared between Washington and Moscow that underscored the fragility of international efforts to end the Bosnian war.

title: In Clinton Harassment Suit, the Stories Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks' Streak Crumbles At Metrodome
description: Blame it on a blister, the bullpen and bumbling outfield play. Blame it all on the Yankees. The wondrous winning streak that continued for 10 games with beautiful and blemished victories finally ended tonight against the Twins. Blame it on them, too.

title: For Pasta, the Bite of Arugula in a Creamy Sauce
description: SERIOUS fans of arugula have tried it in salads, as a base under fish dishes and combined with rice to make risotto. Now, they can try it in a pasta sauce.

title: Edgar A. Grunwald; Magazine Editor, 84
description: Edgar A. Grunwald, an executive of the McGraw-Hill publishing company for more than 25 years, died on Friday at his home in Northport, L.I. He was 84.

title: Bad Lyme Disease Season Expected
description: RESIDENTS of the Northeast could be facing a particularly bad year for Lyme disease, according to scientists at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in Hartford.

title: Arguments Begin at Trial On Citadel's Male Policy
description: Lawyers this week began arguments over Shannon Faulkner's right to attend The Citadel, one of two remaining state-sponsored, all-male military colleges in the country, in which she is enrolled. The first two days of testimony have been used to sketch the case as a matter of equal rights guaranteed by the Constitution versus the benefits of academic diversity in South Carolina's educational system.

title: ISRAELIS OFFERING TO LEAVE GOLAN, NEGOTIATORS SAY
description: Israel has offered to withdraw from the Golan Heights in three phases over five to eight years in return for peace with Syria and normal relations, officials involved in the indirect peace talks said today.

title: Principal Charged With Stealing Funds
description: A Brooklyn school principal was charged yesterday with stealing nearly $10,000 in public school funds and, in a separate case, with coercing teachers into joining a political club so it could be stacked to endorse an ally who was running in school board and City Council elections.

title: Commencements; Secretary of Air Force Encourages Barnard Graduates
description: The first woman to head a branch of the United States military addressed Barnard College's class of 1994 yesterday, telling the 550 graduates of the women's college that their presence would enhance any environment they chose to enter and that their success would help women who follow them.

title: To Change China
description: To the Editor:

title: AGREEMENTS FOR SYSTEMS TO SEND DATA OVER CABLE
description: The Intel Corporation and the General Instrument Corporation will sign agreements with Tele-Communications Inc. and Rogers Cablesystems Ltd. of Canada to develop systems that will permit transmission of computer data over cable systems at speeds of up to 30 million bits a second. The systems will also permit personal computer users to send information upstream, but at slower rates. Similar agreements were signed last year with the Comcast Corporation and Viacom Inc. The technology, which is faster than a similar system being marketed by Zenith, is expected to make it possible to deliver multimedia information, including video, to personal computers in the home.

title: Schilling to Have Surgery
description: Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Curt Schilling will have surgery Friday to remove bone spurs from his right elbow, the team said today.

title: Heigh-Ho! It's Off to Reassess We Go!
description: Not much is predictable in the movie business, but the closest thing to a sure bet is that Disney's new animated musical, "The Lion King," which is to open on June 15 in New York and Los Angeles, will emerge as one of the summer's biggest hits. That's the good news for the Walt Disney Company.

title: On the Brink With North Korea
description: Tiring of cat-and-mouse bargaining with North Korea over its nuclear program, the two Senate leaders, George Mitchell and Robert Dole, want to rush to impose economic sanctions. Their impatience is especially ill timed: international inspectors arrived yesterday at the site of the North's nuclear reactor, which has been shut down for refueling. A move to sanctions is almost sure to get them sent home.

title: Let's Stop Making Myths and Scapegoats of Those on Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Woolworth Vindicates Executives
description: The Woolworth Corporation released a report yesterday clearing its senior executives of wrongdoing in accounting irregularities that caused it to misstate some interim quarterly results in 1992 and 1993.

title: Defining the Problem
description: To The Home Section:

title: Florida State Kicker Suspended
description: Kicker SCOTT BENTLEY was one of two Florida State football players suspended by Coach BOBBY BOWDEN yesterday. Bowden also suspended reserve tight end KAMAI CHARLTON from the Seminoles' national championship team.

title: Lewis Jumping at the Chance to Show He's Not Through
description: Sunday, in his first long jump since winning a gold medal at the 1992 Summer Olympics, Carl Lewis is looking to go over the rainbow, lest anyone think he is gone over the hill.

title:
CURRENTS;
In London, a Habitat Anniversary
description: IN 1964, when paper minidresses and Lucite coffee tables were all the rage, Terence Conran put his money on good, practical design -- furniture, fabrics, lighting, kitchenware and carpets -- sold at affordable prices. His pioneering store, Habitat, on Fulham Road in London, spawned many others. In the United States the stores were called Conran's Habitat.

title: Humocaro Alto Journal; Rebel Is Free to Fish in Venezuela's Roiling Waters
description: A spring storm swept down from Andean coffee fields and rattled across the tile roofs of this mountain village, but the powerfully built man speaking in the central plaza stood his ground, solid as a tree stump.

title: CEMEX UNIT TO BUY SOME LAFARGE ASSETS FOR $100 MILLION
description: The Lafarge Corporation, based in Reston, Va., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell construction materials assets in Texas to a unit of Cemex, Mexico's huge cement company, for $100 million. Sunbelt Acquisitions Inc., the Cemex unit, will buy Lafarge's 900,000-ton cement plant in New Braunfels. It will also buy four cement-storage silos in Houston, Fort Worth, Tyler and Katy, and a 52 percent interest in the Parker Lafarge unit, which operates asphalt and aggregate plants in Houston and New Braunfels.

title: Etienne Hirsch, 93, Backer of a Europe United Like the U.S.
description: Etienne Hirsch, a French administrator who was a leading advocate of a United States of Europe, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 93 and lived in nearby Sevres.

title: SHARES OF BLYTH INDUSTRIES RISE ON FIRST TRADING DAY
description: Shares of Blyth Industries rose 14 percent in their first day of trading after a $53.5 million initial public offering. Blyth, a candle maker, is based in Greenwich, Conn. Its shares closed at $18.875 on the New York Stock Exchange, up from the offering price of $16.50, on volume of 967,800 shares. Of the 3.24 million shares sold, representing a 23 percent stake in the company, 2 million were sold by the company and 1.24 million by a group of shareholders.

SOUTHEAST ASIANS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON WELFARE IN U.S.
description: Nearly 20 years after the end of the war in Southeast Asia brought thousands of Cambodians, Laotians and Vietnamese refugees to this country, many still languish in poverty, giving Southeast Asians the highest rate of welfare dependency of any racial or ethnic group.

title: On the Drag Strip, Oxygen = More Power
description: When the National Hot Rod Association holds its Mopar Parts Nationals at Raceway Park in Old Bridge Township, N. J., this weekend, Eddie Hill and the rest of his drag-racing competitors will be enjoying the sylvan wooded surroundings at the central New Jersey drag strip. But that does not necessarily make them a bunch of rabid environmentalists.

description: Despite their optimistic public remarks about the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, International Olympic Committee officials are concerned about the lack of a government safety net in case organizers cannot meet fund-raising projections.

title: Sony Starts a Division To Sell Game Machines
description: Seeking to stake out turf in the increasingly competitive video-game market, the Sony Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a unit called Sony Computer Entertainment of America to market a CD-based video game machine, which is scheduled to be introduced in the United States in 1995.

description: Wherehouse Entertainment said that the latest year's net loss included ''the effect of the company's previously announced determination to change to a more accelerated video depreciation method and recognize charges for corporate restructuring, resulting in an aggregate charge of about $ 34.5 million.''The company said that the net loss for 1993 included results for the period prior to June 1992, when the company was acquired by affiliates of Merrill Lynch.

description: A bitter battle that had split one of Washington's most prominent retailing families has ended in a court settlement under which the family's patriarch, Herbert H. Haft, will retain control of the family's companies, which include the Dart Group, Crown Books and Trak Auto.

title: Kremlin Gossip, a Best Seller, Is Translated
description: Even with the explosion of historical research and truth-seeking that has been taking place in the former Soviet Union, few Russians had discovered what really happened behind the scenes when the Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, declared war on Germany on June 22, 1941.

title: Family Shift Is Expected For Seagram
description: The heir apparent at the Seagram Company, Edgar Bronfman Jr., is likely to be named the company's chief executive on June 1 at its annual meeting in Montreal, officials close to Seagram said yesterday.

HOUSE PROUD;
From Crawl Space to Spacious Aerie
description: THE attic is the seat of the soul, architecturally speaking. Some attics perch like gnarled crowns atop structures, puzzle boxes concealing layers of memories. They are places where beloved old clothes, paintings, pictures and forgotten toys that parents can't let go of acquire a musty odor.

title: QVC Inc.(QVCN,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a credit of $ 3,990,000, or 8 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Latest first quarter's revenue represented net revenues. QVC said that net revenue in the latest quarter ''should be considered in light of strong net revenue growth'' in the first quarter of 1993.

title: Review/Television; Two Posthumous Tales From Rod Serling
description: It's a sweep month, and the networks are scurrying to bolster ratings that will determine their local stations' ad revenues for the next quarter. Specials are on prominent display, things like a Stephen King mini-series or still another movie about the creepy Menendez brothers. On the less-expensive front are weekly series with the season's final episodes offering cliffhangers. And, as always in commercial television, there are assorted forays into the past.

title: Kings Dismiss Two Executives
description: The Los Angeles Kings, who failed to make the playoffs a year after advancing to the Stanley Cup finals, fired NICK BEVERLEY, their general manager, and BOB OWEN, their player personnel director.

title: Gitano Officials Are Sentenced
description: A Federal judge sentenced each of the two co-founders of Gitano Group Inc. to six months of home detention and three years' probation and ordered them to pay $20,000 fines for customs violations.

title: Sports of The Times; Attention: The Series Isn't Over
description: HUBERT DAVIS saved Patrick Ewing. He saved every Knick, and Pat Riley, too. He played 14 minutes, then walked into every kid's fantasy, and some players' nightmare. Not Davis's. He stepped up to the free-throw line with 2.1 seconds left and made a couple. He saved the Knicks' season and Ewing's championship dream. The Knicks survived, which is the only way to describe how they got out of last night.

title: Books of The Times; Peggy Noonan Recounts Her Century-End Jitters
description: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness By Peggy Noonan 255 pages. Random House. $23.

CURRENTS;
Nothing European About It
description: THE globe lights, quilted stainless-steel panels and marble-chip tiles say it all. The ambiance of the Daily Cafe, 150 East 52d Street, is intentionally American, circa 1960. "The owners are from Seattle and didn't want an espresso bar to look like a Euro-slick cafe," said Henry Myerberg, a New York architect. He designed the cafe with Tucker Viemeister, a graphic designer, for Andrew Price and David Knudsen, who are opening a string of Daily Cafes.

title: Teledyne Wins Small Court Victory in Chilean Sale in 80's
description: A Los Angeles military contractor, accused of illegally exporting an ingredient that ended up in Iraqi cluster bombs, won a partial victory today when a Federal judge here ruled that limited evidence could be presented at the company's coming trial to try to show that the United States allowed the sales for military purposes.

title: No Headline
description: "Foreign statesmen will surely make mistakes in their decisions if they base their understanding of China merely on the words or views of a tiny number of Chinese, and ignore the interests and wishes of all other Chinese people." -- PRIME MINISTER LI PENG. [ A1:1. ]

title: Julie Noel Gilbert, Tax Lawyer, 48
description: Julie Noel Gilbert, 48, who spent her 20-year professional career as a lawyer in Washington, became a partner in Morgan, Lewis & Bockius in 1985 after its merger with the tax firm of Cohen & Uretz, where she had practiced previously.

title: With the end of monopolies, California utilities prepare to take self-promotion more seriously.
description: THANKS to California regulators, a huge industrial sector that now spends a pittance on building its image and market share is expected to change its habits.

title: A Rank That Rankles: New York Slips to No. 3; Now Texas Is 2d Most Populous State
description: New York, first in the American League, second in apple production, has slipped to third in population, behind not only California but now Texas.

title: L.I. Police Arrest 51 In Drug Crackdown
description: In a series of early-morning drug raids, the Suffolk County police arrested 51 people today, including the owners of a video store in St. James who the police said were selling $75,000 worth of cocaine a week.

title: For Whitman, Applause in the Early Acts
description: Take it or leave it, Christine Todd Whitman has been saying since she took office four months ago, pressing her unwavering drive for lower taxes and smaller, more efficient government.

title: Police Stops For Truancy Include Errors
description: A new police campaign aimed at getting truant students off the streets has returned many to class, but some parents have complained that the police have been overeager and are picking up students with legitimate excuses, school officials said yesterday.

title: Salomon's Former Chief Is Rebuffed on Pay Claim
description: John H. Gutfreund, whose tenure as chairman of Salomon Brothers ended in scandal in 1991, has lost a bid to collect $55.3 million in compensation from the firm he once ran -- a figure that largely reflected the strong rebound in the company's stock since he was ousted.

title: Petrie Leaves Post in Portland
description: GEOFF PETRIE said yesterday that his decision to resign as head of basketball operations for the Portland Trail Blazers was no spur of the moment decision. But he declined to be specific about his reasons for quitting a post he has held the last four years.

title: Robertson-Ceco Corp.(RHH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: (Loss)Shares outstanding and per-share net losses reflected the 1-for-16.5 reverse stock split last July.The latest quarter included a restructuring charge of $ 900,000 related to work-force reductions at the building products group and a $ 1.2 million credit from a settlement of claims relating to a project from 1989.

title: Bomb Sent to ABC Offices
description: A device that appeared to be a bomb and was in a package addressed to the president of ABC was delivered to the network's headquarters on the Upper West Side yesterday, but it was deactivated by the police bomb squad, the police said.

title: CHINA SEES RISK TO ITS STABILITY IN U.S. DEMANDS
description: China's leaders have told the United States that they are willing to make further gestures on human rights to build more constructive relations. But they have asked for understanding on what they see as the need to clamp down on dissent and preserve "social stability."

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 25 about a move to recognize gay marriages in Hawaii misstated the number of communities in which benefits are extended to domestic partners of municipal employees. Before Austin, Tex., repealed its ordinance this month, there were 15, not 150.

title: Fred's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Artists Win Round No. 1 In Dispute Over a Sculpture
description: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Helmsley-Spear, the owners of a former Macy's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, may not dismantle a sculptural installation in the lobby of the building, at 47-44 31st Street, until a civil suit brought by the three artists who created it has been resolved. The artists are John J. Veronis, John Swing and John Carter.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO. (CPB,N)
description: The Campbell Soup Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose more than 13 percent in its fiscal third quarter, but the gain was less than analysts' expectations and some lowered their investment ratings on the company's stock.

title: Suspended Driver Is at Wheel of Car That Kills Professor
description: The students at York College began to file into Classroom D-401 shortly before 2 P.M. There was nothing on the blackboards, and no books were opened. The final exam had to be rescheduled because funeral arrangements were being made.

description: In an apparent victory for the United States, the Japanese Government is expected to abandon a plan to revise its copyright law in a way that would have made it easier for one company to reverse-engineer another company's computer software.

title: Mail Call
description: This is what happens when you send electronic mail, as millions of Americans now do. Your fingers fly; so, in a sense, do your words; and you never run out of stamps. But if you're the recipient and the correspondence is personal, you are not getting all the message.

His method was to provoke and ultimately humiliate the President of the United States by brutalizing and then torturing one of our citizens.

description: In a French court ruling that may give fashion the same sort of copyright protection offered to software and art in America, Yves Saint Laurent won a total of $395,090 from Ralph Lauren yesterday, for "counterfeiting and disloyal competition."

description: The London Financial Futures and Options Exchange announced this week that it would not join the Globex 24-hour trading system because of the limitations such an agreement would impose on its future development.

description: Alain Cuny, a tall and ascetic-looking French actor who seemed made to play priests and aristocrats, died on Monday night at the Cochin Hospital in Paris. He was 85.

title: Japanese Premier Seeking To Limit Nuisance Taxes
description: Japan's new Prime Minister, Tsutomu Hata, responded today to growing public criticism of a wave of steep increases in government-controlled fees and tolls by ordering bureaucrats to freeze the fees at their current levels until the end of the year.

title: Bad Backdoor Deal on Health Care
description: Chairman Dan Rostenkowski of the House Ways and Means Committee has offered a prominent group of health insurers a deal on health care reform. Mr. Rostenkowski promises to drop several provisions odious to the insurers if they agree to stop squawking about others. The proposed deal might be a victory for Mr. Rostenkowski -- who is fighting to save his chairmanship by plea-bargaining with prosecutors over accusations of financial improprieties; it might be good for the insurance companies. But it looks bad for everyone else.

title: Jose Trias, Julie Gilbert, Lawyers in Capital, Slain
description: Jose Enrique Trias, 49, and his wife, Julie Noel Gilbert, 48, tax lawyers from Bethesda, Md., were found dead of gunshots in the head in their weekend home near Annapolis on Monday. The authorities said they had apparently been killed in a robbery.

title: A New Mantra From Utility Companies: Use More Electricity
description: HALF a million households around the country will soon receive catalogues that look as if they came from a time warp: sent by local electric utilities, they promote using more electricity.

title: Small Outfits Find Backers In F.C.C. Bids
description: Steven Zecola is the head of a tiny company that plans to take advantage of generous new Federal rules intended to help small businesses start wireless telephone services. His partner is the not-so-tiny Fidelity Investments, one of the nation's biggest mutual fund companies.

title: Telescopes Set to View A Cosmic Collision
description: Most of the world's telescopes on the ground and in space will be pointed at Jupiter this summer, watching for a cosmic collision that is certain to happen and waiting to give scientists their first view of the kind of catastrophic event that may have accounted for mass extinctions on Earth long ago and the eventual emergence of humans.

title: After Serb Forces Shell Airport, U.N. Cancels 3 Flights to Tuzla
description: The United Nations canceled three planned flights into the northern Bosnian city of Tuzla today, only a day after Bosnian Serb forces shelled the first plane to land at the airfield in over a month.

description: In a concession to Russian pride, NATO said today that the alliance's relationship with Russia could be broader than the so-called Partnership for Peace the allies offered to it and the other formerly Communist countries in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, officials said.

title: Streak Seems Distant As the Yankees Take Even Steeper Tumble
description: Suddenly, the Yankees, hailed as the best team in baseball, looked ordinary. Forget that; they looked less than ordinary. And after their pitching failed so miserably, their fielders mishandled two fly balls and their batters hardly stirred before the seventh-inning stretch, the Yankees looked like downright imposters today in a 13-5 thrashing by the Minnesota Twins.

title: Assembly Delays Bill to Keep New York City Out of Debt
description: Although New York City faces cash-flow problems this week because of delays in state aid, the Democratic-controlled State Assembly has postponed until at least Monday approval of a $660 million infusion of emergency aid for the city.

title: Marlins' Old-Timers Leave Mets Mystified
description: Charlie Hough is 46 years old, he throws a knuckleball, and he split his fingernail the other day. That's almost like a kicker in football breaking his big toe.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: UNLICENSED DRIVER CHARGED IN DEATH There was nothing on the blackboards, and no books were open. The final exam had to be rescheduled because funeral arrangements were being made. Psychology 206 no longer had a teacher. James Donald Wynne, who was adored by his students at York College, died after he was struck by a car driven by a man with a suspended license. A1. AN EAGER INMATE CONFOUNDS THE SYSTEM Every now and then, Gangaram Mahes slips on his best donated clothes, strolls to a nice restaurant and savors a $50 meal. The waiters call him sir, but Mr. Mahes could not dig a dollar from his pocket for a bus ride to heaven. He is a thief who never runs, a criminal who picks his teeth as the police close in. To be arrested, to go home to a cell at Rikers Island, is his plan when he unfolds his napkin. A1.

title: Morgan Stanley Reports 41% Drop in Profit
description: Anyone wondering just how gruesome the last few months have been for bond traders got a clear look yesterday, as Morgan Stanley Group Inc. announced a drop of 41 percent in its profits for the three months that ended on April 30.

title: Review/Music; A Forgotten U.S. Composer Is Resurrected
description: One of the functions of the American Composers Orchestra is to root out music that after a few moments of prominence has simply died away. Edward Joseph Collins was, for example, somewhat of a Midwestern darling during the first half of this century. Program notes for the orchestra's concert on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall tell us that between 1924 and 1941 the Chicago Symphony played three of Collins's piano concertos and two other orchestra pieces. The listener is indebted for the information, for Collins's name is absent from the most prominent reference books now in circulation.

title: With Israel Gone, Jericho Takes First Slow Steps to Self-Rule
description: The Jericho post office was open today, but since it lacked Palestinian stamps, no one could send any letters.

title: Guessing At French Baroque Staging
description: Every age has its ferocious battles over matters of musical style. Adherents of Wagner and Brahms considered each others' heroes the bane of musical culture. More recently, Minimalists and Serialists have hurled brickbats at each other. Usually, both sides find their place in the repertory, leaving future generations to wonder what all the fuss was about.

title: A Game of Shame in Albany
description: What will convince the dawdlers in New York State's Legislature that it is time for a budget? The fiscal year begins -- began -- 49 days ago, on April 1. Only once in the 12 years since Mario Cuomo became Governor has budget enactment been later than it is today. The people's elected representatives deserve nothing but contempt for their sorry performance.

title: U.S. Tries to Hide Indian Ruins From Intruders
description: Forget about finding this place on a road map ever again. And don't bother looking for Cutthroat Castle nearby.

title: Italy's New Rightist Cabinet Wins Slim Senate Approval
description: Italy's new right-wing Government scraped through a confidence vote in the Senate tonight, crowning the electoral triumph of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and his neo-Fascist and Northern League allies.

title: DEVON SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE ACQUISITION OF ALTA
description: The shareholders of the Devon Energy Corporation approved the acquisition of the Alta Energy Corporation of Midland, Tex., for $64.6 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. Alta shareholders of record will receive 35 cents a share in cash and three-tenths of a Devon common share if they own more than 334 shares. Holders of fewer Alta shares will get $7.14 a share in cash. The price includes $39 million in debt that Devon will assume. Devon, based in Oklahoma City, will pay about $1.4 million in cash and issue 1.18 million of its common shares to Alta shareholders.

title: Chief of Pension Fund Leaving in California
description: Dale M. Hanson, one of the leaders in the movement to strengthen shareholders' rights, is expected to announce today that he is stepping down as the chief executive of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund, on July 1.

Maxx division had strong sales in March, which produced ''healthy gains in operating income despite softness experienced in the sales of apparel during April.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP., West Lafayette, Ind., said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 5 million of its 69.9 million common shares outstanding.

description: City Council committee chairmen angrily criticized high-ranking members of the Giuliani administration at budget hearings yesterday, accusing some commissioners of not being forthcoming about how services will be affected by the Mayor's proposed budget cuts.

title: Arafat and Peres, at a Meeting in Oslo, Accentuate the Positive
description: On the day Israel surrendered control of Gaza to the Palestinians, Yasir Arafat and Shimon Peres met here today for a celebration in the city where their journey toward peaceful cooperation began secretly nearly two years ago.

title: Dow Climbs by 12.28 in a Late Recovery
description: It was a baffling day in the markets yesterday, as traders pondered the steep interest-rate increase they had long lobbied for and got. The stock market drifted in the morning, but recovered strongly in the afternoon, especially as measured by the broad-based Standard & Poor's 500.

title: Israel Finishes Withdrawing Troops From the Gaza Strip
description: Relieved to lay down the burden but nervous about what lies ahead, Israel completed its army withdrawal from Palestinian towns and refugee camps in the Gaza Strip today.

title: 2 Prominent Tax Lawyers Are Found Slain in Maryland Weekend Home
description: The two tax lawyers from Bethesda came to their gray and white clapboard house here with the notion of getting away from the stress of their daily lives. Instead, they were killed sometime over the weekend in the newly renovated home just outside Annapolis.

title: Russians and Americans Join in Anti-Abortion Fight
description: A French geneticist showed slides of a curled fetus the size of a button and just as cute. A Russian Orthodox priest explained what he called the direct corollary between abortion and divorce. And American anti-abortion advocates advised their Russian counterparts always to refer to a fetus as a child, and abortion as murder.

description: b-After a charge of $ 300,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Shiloh Industries said that year-ago second quarter pro forma share earnings are 25 cents, adjusted to reflect the company's initial public offering on June 29, 1993.Year-ago 6 months' pro forma share earnings are 40 cents.The pro forma figures treat the June 1993 reorganization, initial public offering and repayment of debt as if they occurred at the beginning of the 1993 fiscal year.Shiloh said this year's second quarter LIFO charge exceeded that of a year ago by 1 cent a share.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN SEES CUTS OF $250 MILLION A YEAR
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation plans to slash costs by $250 million a year as it absorbs the former Grumman Corporation and prepares for an era of leaner Pentagon budgets. To increase profits, the company will consolidate management at its Los Angeles headquarters and eliminate operations that may be duplicated in the company's facilities, said Kent Kresa, the president and chief executive. The goal is to reduce operating costs by $250 million a year, beginning in 1995, Mr. Kresa said. He did not specify how many layoffs were planned, on top of the 4,500 layoffs Grumman and Northrop already planned for this year. The company is poised for "double-digit earnings growth" beginning next year, Mr. Kresa said in a speech at the annual meeting in Los Angeles yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The ascension of JAMES TRUMAN, 36, the new editorial director of Conde Nast Publications, one of the most influential jobs in magazine publishing, was celebrated on Tuesday night at a party given by ANNA WINTOUR, the editor in chief of Vogue; TINA BROWN, the editor in chief of The New Yorker; GABE DOPPELT, the former editor in chief of Mademoiselle, and BRYAN FERRY, the British rocker.

title: Health Care Hearings Open in Squabble
description: Two Congressional committees took up national health insurance today, and the discussions promptly dissolved into the sort of cranky partisan squabbling that has kept the subject off the statute books since it was first proposed a half century ago.

description: New Financial Rules Sought
